You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License along with this program. If not, see <http://www.gnu.org/licenses>.

Reverse Polish Notation (RPN) is an alternative to infix notation, i.e. rather than writing the operator in between the operands (2 + 2), you will write the operator after the operands (2 2 +).
 
Let's calculate
 
(3 + 4) × 2
 
Notice how we have to place parentheses around the first part of the expression because, in infix notation, the multiplication operator has a higher precedence than the addition operator, and parentheses have a higher precendence still. In reverse polish notation, there is no operator precedence. We can simply type
 
3 4 + 2 ×
 
Note how the expression could only have been written this way. If we got rid of the parentheses, we would translate the expression to 3 4 2 × + instead.
 
Imagine a stack of numbers. Typing 3 and then Enter will put the number 3 on the stack. With one number on the stack, we can do operations that only need one operand, like negating the number (+/−). If we now type another 3, we can (immediately) use an operator that takes two operands, such as +.
 
In our example, (3 + 4) × 2, the stack will evolve like this:
 
3 
3 4 
7 
7 2 
14 

For more information, see: 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_Polish_notation
